direction.raw_text: ! That's a beautiful name... French? Jean sits in a chair onstage with his band members. Benny plays the organ. The other band members play percussion and guitar. It works. The crowd loves it. The song ends abruptly. We begin to hear James Brown's "Sex Machine." Jean looks out into the crowd and notices Gina. She's looking right back at him from the bar. Pleased to see her face, he says to himself -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boom, for real. We see him walk offstage into the crowd. They meet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you hated this place?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do. (beat) I just said that. I was never here before. I actually like it. MUSIC segues into PIL's "Public Image".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's get out of here. He leads her towards the exit. They step out of the club. EXT. MUDD CLUB - NIGHT HIGH, WIDE ANGLE It's raining heavily. Jean motions for Gina to wait under the entrance. He tries to hail a cab... And another. And another. A parade of them passes, but each time they slow down, they get a glimpse of Jean and drive off. Finally, Gina steps out of the entrance. She raises her hand, and a car pulls over instantly. INT. CAB - NIGHT They scurry into the backseat. The cab pulls off. EXT. CHINESE RESTAURANT - NIGHT Through a steamy, rain-wet window, we see Jean and Gina seated at a table, dining. They seem to be having a nice time. INT. GINA'S APARTMENT - NEXT MORNING Gina lays in bed. Daylight streams into the apartment. Jackhammers RATTLE outside. (Music: REGGAE SONG - Errol Scorcher's "Cockroach in de Corner.") EXTREME CLOSEUP A cockroach crawls from Gina's bedroom across the floor and into the kitchen where Jean sits naked on the floor, working on a drawing. It crawls over his drawing towards a cardboard box. Jean rummages through a cabinet. He finds a can of bugspray. Jean tears off a side of the box. With cardboard in one hand and bugspray in the other, he forgets the cockroach. He's mesmerized by the list of ingredients on the aerosol can. Someone POUNDS furiously at the door. Ignoring the pounding, he starts listing the ingredients on the piece of cardboard, finishing his new drawing by including a symbol of a cockroach to the left of the list.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Cardinale... Open up for me, please! He gets up and peeks through the security hole. He sees a middle- aged Hispanic woman reaching to unlock the door. He opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ohhh, Dios mio! She stares at him levelly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just want the rent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why didn't you say so? Damn! She's asleep! Jean draws on a piece of paper on the counter next to him. He hands it to the landlady. It's a a little shack with a big head next to it that says "'Here' For Rent." The landlady looks at him like he's crazy. She balls up the drawing and puts it in her pocket. Gina arrives in the doorway, wearing a robe. The landlady's trapped between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Jean) What're you doing? The landlady wags her finger at Gina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next Monday. Gina and Jean look amused as they watch her leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wanna go get some breakfast?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A friend of mine offered me a job doing a little work installing a show in a gallery. He's an electrician. I was supposed to be there an hour ago. She looks at the bugspray drawing on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ohh, that's nice. Jean kisses her neck as she looks at the drawing. We HOLD on the drawing. INT. MARY BOONE GALLERY - DAY White dust sprinkles down onto Jean's face from the ceiling. Unable to use his hands, he tries to blow the dust out of his eyes... His boss, GREG, a mild-mannered hippie electrician, works above him on the ladder. Jean steadies the ladder. Greg's head is out of frame. The gallery is an impressive space under preparations for an opening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jean, could you get me a Phillips screwdriver?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phillips head. From the toolbox.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Jean searches through the toolbox. He picks up a screwdriver and reads the handle: "CRAFTSMAN" BASQUIAT (CONT'D) 'Phillips head,' right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Jean shakes his head and puts it back. He tries a couple more - they each say "CRAFTSMAN." He puts them back. Finally, he finds one with a different handle. It says "G.S.C. 2000."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have any!!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's impossible. I've got, like, five of 'em! He comes down off the ladder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're holding one in your hand!!! (beat) You've never done this kind of work before, have you? (demonstrating) See, this is a regular screwdriver, and this is a Phillips head. The cross thing... I'll tell you later what all the tools are so you'll know. A GROUP of people arrives. Albert Milo    comes into view, tailed closely by Rene Ricard and MARY BOONE    - well dressed, petite, intense, 30. Milo, (also about 30), wears    casual clothes splattered with paint. Mary Boone is engaged in    conversation with Milo. Rene chatters away. Greg climbs back up the ladder. He holds a piece of wire down to Jean. Jean stares at the group while trying to be invisible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need to make a call, Mary. You don't mind, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly not. You can use my line. Rene picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To Paris. Bernard Picasso - (to Mary) You know Bernard -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be my guest. Jean watches the group talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jean? Hold this, please. (beat - he sees why Jean's so distracted) You'll get there. But it's good to have something to fall back on. That's why I became an electrician. It pays the rent. Y'know, I'm an artist, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sculpt. I'm really just starting to find myself. How old are you? Twenty? You're just like I used to be. I'm forty-one. And I'm glad I haven't gotten any recognition. It gave me time to develop. Jean watches Mary and Milo talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Milo) I can't tell you how happy I am with this show. Mary yells across the room to Jean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (her tone impersonal) Excuse me - you - what's your name? Would you move those tools there and put them somewhere else? He looks at her. Milo watches to see what he's going to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Milo) My name is Jean Michel Basquiat. Have you heard of me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (amused) No. Should I have?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a painter, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really. Huh. Too bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, would you please move those tools? Jean looks at Milo. Milo looks back at him. Jean walks past the tools and continues toward the door. He walks out without turning around. Milo smiles to himself. EXT. BOONE GALLERY - ALBERT MILO OPENING - DUSK The ART WORLD CROWD fills the gallery. Jean lurks across the street, watching through the window. Cabs and limousines line the block. A crowd outside blocks the street. Jean's obviously impressed, jealous and estranged -     he feels entitled to all this. He crosses the street to get a closer look. THROUGH THE WINDOW He sees Albert Milo    talking with ANDY WARHOL and BRUNO BISCHOFBERGER. Andy,    of course, is thin, silver-haired, and nearly albino. Bruno    is a Swiss art dealer in his 40's. He exudes money - a pillar of    security. On the other side of the room, Rene Ricard is surrounded by a coterie of young, mostly BLACK AND HISPANIC MALES. Rene looks drunk, enjoying the moment, holding court. Rene crosses to Albert and Andy. People pass by. Jean starts to walk. About half a block away, he sprays on a wall: "THE WHOLE LIVERY LINE BOW LIKE THIS WITH THE BIG MONEY ALL CRUSHED INTO THESE FEET" He looks pleased. He turns and looks up West Broadway beyond the buildings at the sky: SUPERIMPOSED IN THE SKY We see a surfer emerging from a HUGE WAVE. He looks powerful and exalted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. BASKETBALL COURT - DAY ANGLE ON: A wall. We see the following graffity: "JIMMY BEST ON HIS BACK TO THE SUCKERPUNCH OF HIS CHILDHOOD YEARS" A basketball bounces against a wall. Jean and Benny amble onto a basketball court. Jean's changed his hairstyle. Now the dreadlocks stand straight up from his head. Benny dribbles with skill while Jean puffs furiously on a cigarette. He doesn't look like he's slept, but he's happy. Benny throws the ball to Jean. It bounces off a puddle and splashes Jean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Jean. Get rid of your cigarette. Concentrate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am... On Gina. (beat) Fuck - I didn't think we were actually gonna do this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Concentrate on the ball. Shoot. Jean shoots. It flies up, up, up -     and over the backboard. He runs after the ball, gets it, and dribbles clumsily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're shattering all my myths.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh - you mean black people! He shoots and misses again. He throws it to Benny, who does a picture-perfect lay-up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (changing the subject) How long do you think it takes to get really famous? During the following, Benny performs a series of amazing shots while Jean looks on admiringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a musician or a painter? Jean shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever. Famous. To where you can do your stuff all day without thinking about anything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ummm... Four years. Six to get rich. He shoots. Swish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First, you have to dress right. He shoots again. Swish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, you have to hang out all the time - with famous people - the right people, the right chicks, the right parties. He shoots again. Swish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you gotta do your work all the time when you're not doing that. The same kinda work, the same style - over and over again, so people recognize it and don't get confused. Then, once you're famous, you have to keep doing it the same way, even after it's boring - unless you want people to really get mad at you - which they will anyway. Benny tosses Jean the ball. Jean walks off the court.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. I hate this. I'm no good at it. Jean shoots the ball and keeps walking. The ball goes in. He doesn't notice. Benny runs after it. EXT. HOUSTON ST. - DUSK Benny and Jean walk along. Benny dribbles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Famous people are usually pretty stupid. You're too smart. You'd get bored to death. You don't wanna be like John Henry - fighting the machine. Just do what you do. It's about integrity. Follow your heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's John Henry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh man! Folklore guy - worked on the railroad. Y'know, pounding in spikes and laying down track. Then one day they invented a machine to do it. And he says "Fuck that, I'm a MAN" and he challenges the machine to a race to lay down a mile of track. It takes two days. Neck and neck the whole time. They get right to the end, and he beats it by one spike. (pause) Got a cigarette?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So then what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drops dead! See? Just do your shit like you do it! Your friends like you, you get laid, everyone walks by, sees your stuff everywhere. It's good. What else do you want? They watch a long stretch limo cruises up across the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like I said - my liquid hijack Marlboros. (indicates limo) Check it out. The LIMO DRIVER opens the back door. Andy Warhol and Bruno Bischofberger step out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andy Warhol. He's famous and he's not boring. INSERT: AN IMAGE OF ANDY'S PAINTINGS AT THE WHITNEY MUSEUM (FOOTAGE FROM JONAS MEKAS FILM) Jean scrounges in his pockets, pulls out his Xerox cards, and readies himself as Bruno and Andy enter BALLATO'S RESTAURANT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What're you doing? You're doing something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's the best painter in the world. I'm gonna give him one of these.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't give him anything, man. Your art's worth a lot. Trade. That's what real artists do with each other. Besides, he'll just use you. He's famous for that. Benny watches Jean crosses the street. Jean passes the limousine. Inside, the driver (a 24-year old Rasta) takes a hit from a joint and watches Jean. CLOSE ON The driver's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DRIVER'S POV: He watches Jean cross the street. Jean enters the restaurant. INT. BALLATO'S - DAY Jean enters. Andy and Bruno spot him. The Maitre'd becomes alarmed. but it's too late - he's at their table. He spreads his cards on the table. The topmost card reads "REDEEMABLE BECAUSE OF HIS YOUTH." Andy stares dead ahead, Sphinxlike. Bruno watches the non-interaction between the two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Jean, flustered) Can I help you?. He taps Jean's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Jean) Sir...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sympathetically) I think it's ok.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, Mr. Bischofberger. Bruno picks up one of the cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wanna buy some ignorant art? Ten bucks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ignorant art?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... Like - stupid, ridiculous, crummy art.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ohhh. That's new. That sounds good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten bucks apiece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can give you five. You didn't do very much to these.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't even work on your stuff!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't matter how much you worked on them. It matters how much you can get for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can get ten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take two. This one and... that one. (to Bruno) Can I borrow some money, Bruno? Bruno pulls out a hundred dollar bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here. Do you have change? As WAITER arrives with the tray, Jean pockets the bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You made a good deal. Here, you can have these, too. He leaves all the cards and walks toward the door. BRUNO'S POV: Jean leaving past stupified Maitre'd. EXT. GINA'S APARTMENT - DAY Jean and Benny are outside the entrance to Gina's building. Jean carries two huge bags overflowing with groceries and flowers. He buzzes. There's no answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be right back. He produces a key and lets himself in. He enters the building. INT. GINA'S APARTMENT - DAY Jean sets the groceries on the counter and leaves. We notice the Bugspray painting on the wall, along with more of Jean's work and supplies. EXT. GINA'S APARTMENT - DUSK Jean rejoins Benny in front of Gina's building. As they're leaving, Gina comes up the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Benny) Check you later, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi Gina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. INT - GINA'S APARTMENT - DAY Flowers and groceries are strewn on the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Over the following MONTAGE we HEAR:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... 'APT 20'... The church bells would ring at noon and six a.m.. 24 strokes: How many times we counted them. We called our bed the cloud. And there we'd float. The bathtub was in the kitchen and took forever to fill up. We'd bathe together afterwards. Oh the countless cigarettes and take out Chinese food... The bed was so narrow Three years we made it fit. The sheets were green the sheets were pink the sheets white linen from the past. Little home, farewell, The broken windows and the bodega on the corner. Now from my balcony I look out over all New York... INT. GINA'S APARTMENT - NIGHT Jean and Gina are sleeping. SERIES OF DISSOLVES: As they're turning together in their sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. KITCHEN / LIVINGROOM (GINA'S APARTMENT) - DAY Filled with Jean's paintings. SERIES OF DISSOLVES: Paintings and objects fill the room. FADE TO BLACK SUPER: "A YEAR AND A HALF LATER EAST 9TH ST." FADE UP: INT. GINA'S APARTMENT - DAY Jean watches "The Little Rascals" on TV in the living room. The sound is turned off and a record player PLAYS Gypsy music loudly. Rolled up in a large drop cloth, Gina is asleep on the floor. Next to her, Jean works on all fours, drawing figures, crowns, and houses. Working feverishly, he writes "HEY, HEY, HEY" in big clusters, then writes other words: SHARK, IMMORTALITY, JOHN THE REVELATOR, FAME, INK, TEETH, HAWAII SUPERMARKET, POLE STAR, BABOON and TAR. He has an acoustics manual and Bible open    on the floor. He copies the technical blueprints from the manual.    He reads the Bible, following the text with a dirty finger. It    seems that he watches TV, draws, listens to the music and reads    at the same time. He mixes Liquitex paints and puts some colors on the drawings. He draws a long blue line and carries it over onto the floor. Up the wall. Through the fridge. Across the window. He takes off his paint-covered clothes and changes into Gina's black slip. He rummages around the room, gathering pieces of his and Gina's clothes. He spreads the clothes on the floor, and selecting wide brushes with long bristles, picks up the cans of Liquitex paint. When paint spills on the clothes, he spreads it into shapes. Gina wakes up. She reaches for one of the painted shirts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in disbelief) Basquiat, those are my best clothes!!! What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, baby, I painted them for you. They're beautiful now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to my parents this weekend. What am I going to wear? (she begins to cry) How could you do that to me? Jean wipes his hands off on his thighs and puts his arms around Gina, holding her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'll buy you some new ones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have any fucking money.. Jean lets her cry for a moment, then notices the music playing on the stereo - a Gypsy song sung in Spanish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know what he's saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What who's saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Manzanita.... (translating song) ... if one day I die, and    you read this piece of paper, I want you    to know how much I love you. Although I'll    never see you again, Gypsy, Gypsy, your    hair, your hair, your face, your face' Gina looks up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Even though you were never mine And you never will be You have a piece of my heart You have, you have, you have...' (he reaches down, wiping off Gina's face) 'Gypsy, Gypsy, your hair, your hair, your face, your face.' No longer crying, Gina leans her head against Jean. We HEAR a CALL from the window:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie Mays!!! Willie Mays!!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (at the window) Come on in!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Benny and two GUYS come barreling into the apartment. Immediate chaos. Benny holds up a packet of drugs and jiggles it temptingly. They make themselves at home. Jean sits with them and starts to chop up the drugs. Gina gives Jean a look. She stands, still wrapped in the drop cloth. She lets it fall to the floor. She's wearing only her underwear. She walks to the bedroom. Benny watches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gina, don't you want any of this? You could use some. Gina doesn't respond. She comes out of the bedroom with a small suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See you later. She leaves. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice underwear... They start to laugh. INT. GINA'S APARTMENT - LATER Kneeling on the floor,    Jean    covers the surface    of the refrigerator door with    fast,    rushing strokes.    He mixes paint in a large soupbowl and dips    his    hair in the bowl.    Pressing his head to the door, he paints    with    his hair. He stops    to examine the marks. He HITS his head against the door harder and harder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GINA'S APARTMENT - MORNING CAMERA PULLS BACK: Revealing Jean's eyes. They're open and motionless. His head is tilted toward his chest. OFF SCREEN WE HEAR the sounds of Gina coming home: The LOCK turns. The door OPENS. Gina comes in and drops a bag on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Basquiat? Silence. She picks up the mail from under the door and walks into the room. There's a lump on the floor. It's Jean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wake up! I'm back! She shakes his arm. No result. She lifts his head, revealing his painted hair. She shakes him harder. His body is totally limp. The whites of his eyes are red; his pupils slowly float up, vanishing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jean, what did you do to yourself? She listens to his breath, then to his heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (panicking) Jesus Christ! She finds heroin sprinkled into some pot on the floor near him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slapping his face) Don't do this to me. She shakes him until his eyes unglue. His pupils float into their proper place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (furious) Oh, God, Basquiat, you scared the shit out of me. How the fuck could you do that to yourself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Monday morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not Sunday? I missed you. You shouldn't leave me alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're blaming me? I had to go see my family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm your family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Basquiat, what did you take? Jean tries to pick himself up from the floor. He gets up stiffly, like Pinnocchio. The long sleep made his limbs wooden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing special - just some weed. He finds an old joint and lights it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Basquiat, don't lie. (holds up powder) This is smack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want some? He offers her the joint. EXT. ST. MARK'S PLACE - NIGHT Jean and Benny walk along, sharing a beer in a brown paper bag. They approach a DRUG DEALER and exchange money for dope. Jean finds a discarded window frame in a pile of trash and carries it with him. They sit down on a stoop. Jean rolls up a dollar bill, empties the dope onto the window, and splits it into two lines. He hands the rolled up bill to Benny, who snorts the line. Benny shakes his head involuntarily, making a violent face, as though the dope burned a hole in his sinus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We got beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For real? Jean takes a taste with his finger... He tastes his tongue and makes a face.. He snorts part of his line, anyway, to make sure. He frowns. They continue onwards. Jean still carries the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You gonna carry that around all night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... I'll paint on it. INT. PARTY - NIGHT The party's winding down - hip-hop kids, Lower East Side types. Jean and Benny pass through the room, ignoring the two or three clusters of people - maybe fifteen in all... Jean encounters a familiar face: an enormous red-haired dealer - ROCKETS (35). They greet each other as friends. Rockets leads Jean aside. They stand near a wall where a painting hangs ("Flats Fixed"). It bears Jean's three-point crown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did that, didn't you? Jean shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gave it to Maripol. She let me stay here for awhile. Jean hands him twenty dollars. Rockets hands him two dime bags. As if thinking better, he hands the bill back to Jean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do one for me and it's free. How's that? Jean re-pockets his money. He gestures to Rockets as if to say "fine - it's a deal." He and Benny sit down across the room and split a bag onto the window, as before. This time, it's good. They lean back into it, slumping down into the couch. Nearby, Rene sits on a couch with THREE STREET KIDS - artists (who we've seen at Milo's opening). They sit on their knees looking out a window passing binoculars back and forth. ARTIST #1 looks through the window with a pair of BINOCULARS. He points down towards the street, trying to get Rene's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Check this out, Rene. Rene lunges towards the window. The stereo BLARES (Curtis Blow's "Survival")
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (singing along) "The name of the game is survival, You learn it in jail upon your arrival!" Another ARTIST (#2) a young black man, runs up and tries to turn down the volume. Rene grabs his crotch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chill, man! Be cool! This isn't even my apartment!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh man, you a FINE nigga! You know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cut it out, man! And don't be callin' me that shit! ANGLE ON: Benny is now alone on the couch. He nods out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (noticing him) Oh my, there goes the neighborhood. Who's house is this, anyway? Artist #2 is still mad at Rene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Artist #2) That's what I like about you straight boys. You're so sensitive!!! (resumes singing) "The name of the game is survival, Survival! Survival! only the strong survive"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rene! Come here, man!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gotta go pee. Rene weaves across the room. Suddenly, he stops cold. He's staring at Jean's painting. He doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to himself) Who did this? (beat - louder) Who did this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I told you, this isn't my apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know who did that. That's Jean Michel's. He's right here, man... He turns to look for Jean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck, man, where'd he go? Where's Jean? Benny looks around ineffectually and shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to himself) It's fucking amazing. Motherfucker's got to put a crown on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling from the window) Rene, man, check this out. Whoa... He's kinda cute. Rene looks to him and back at the painting. He takes one last look. direction.raw_text: A little more to the right, Frank. OK... Good. Now up... You got a little more? Jean notices a bunch of Andy's wigs on a desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's with the wigs?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to send them to my friends for Christmas presents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think those are good presents? Who wants an old wig? Jean makes a grimace. He walks up to the painting Frank's peeing on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Piss painting?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to make a few more of these. Frank's been drinking this Mexican beer. It makes a good green.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come you're not peeing on them yourself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like beer. Looking down at the painting -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you ever want me to shit on 'em, just ask. You could finger paint. INT. THE FACTORY - LATER Jean and Andy collaborate on a large canvas. Andy outlines a Mobil Oil winged horse. Jean paints it out. To the side he paints a penguin with a hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was my favorite part!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can do better. It needed more white. Andy watches as Jean lights a joint and continues working on his penguin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jean, you make me feel worthless. You're so famous. Andy paints an Amoco logo next to the penguin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't even have any friends anymore besides you. And everyone says "Warhol? That death-warmed over person on drugs? He's just using you."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gee. You shouldn't take it so seriously, Jean. That's why you can't stop taking drugs. You always think people don't like you. Everyone likes you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People are only interested in you because you're famous, not because they know a fuckin' thing about your work. Jean paints out part of Andy's logo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bruno called. In    Europe, people are saying you're gonna die    from drugs. They think they can cash in    on your death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I was poor, everybody doubted I could make it. When I got rich, everyone said, `yeah, but he'll never keep it up.' Now everyone says `he's killing himself.' So I clean up, and then they say `Look. His art's dead.' I don't take drugs, anyway. I'm healthy now. Jean obliterates Andy's logo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you say so. You sleep until 5:00 p.m. You call at four in the morning. You never show up anywhere on time - if you show up. You're painting out everything I do! Andy paints back in part of the horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's better. Jean adds some letters on top of Andy's logo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't even see what's good anymore. Jean Michel obliterates the rest of the logo with some white. Andy steps back and squints as he examines Jean's work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I see what you mean about the white. It's better. Jean quits painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After the show we should take a nice long vacation. Maybe go to Hawaii. That's what I'm gonna do. I'm going to give up painting and start playing music again. I wanna sing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That would be a pity because you're a real painter. Frank arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's the poster for the show. He presents them with a yellow poster of Jean and Andy facing each other with boxing gloves. INT. FACTORY - NEXT DAY Shenge hands Andy a box. Andy opens the box. Inside is a football helmet with Jean's dreadlocks glued to the outside. CLOSE UP: Andy in mirror wearing helmet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Number?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A BRUNETTE walks up -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monica.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Number?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Andy's assistant, Frank, arrives with CHRISTINE, 25, a model.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yo, Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is really great. What a nice place. Jean is taken with Christine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you met Christine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so. He's thrown off his rhythm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you sign one of those for me? TOXIC (seen with Rene at loft party earlier) spots Jean and steps in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! Jean, this is Ramellzee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yo... You know why Rammellzee's here, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-oh!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here for an interrogation. You've been called a graffiti artist and I wanna know why. All I see are scribble scrabble abstractions!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boom? As in ordnance? Are your letters armed? What is the prime directive of graffiti culture? Do you know, black man? Jean likes Rammellzee enough to be patient... Toxic grins and rolls his eyes to Jean. Jean watches Christine as they go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Ram, re: Jean) Man, I was up on him years ago on the IRT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're selling and ending the culture. Not one bit of information. Only to get the money and growl with the power, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's ignorant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That ain't ignorant - that's just stupid. (beat - to Christine) Can I get you a bowl of gumbo? Rammellzee yells after him -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This interrogation is not over! Jean escorts Christine to the kitchen. Bruno and Andy stand in the crowd. Nearby are two WOMEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albert Milo? Ugh! He's just a pressmonger. That's all these people do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, I love Jean's early work. It's really got something. But this collaboration with Andy - maybe they thought it was a joke... I mean - whose work is it? Jean's or Andy's? Walking by, Rene responds to this -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His early work? He's only twenty-six! Rene walks over to Jean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Rene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks again for not inviting me. I'm only here on business. Rene heads back out into the party. Jean eats gumbo while Christine thumbs through the Times Magazine. ANGLE ON Rene responds to something Andy's been telling him in a low voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (loudly) You're asking me? Nigga, please. After the way you treated me? This is the first time I've heard from either of you in months! I had to crash this party! You treated me like a suede biscuit. Rene don't play that! I can't get him off drugs! I don't even talk to him any more!!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Bruno) What's a suede biscuit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (amused) Hey, what's this? It says right here you're Andy's... "lapdog"... Jean walks away. He passes through the crowd, making his way to the door. He exits. EXT. GREAT JONES ST LOFT - NIGHT Drugged, upset, Jean leaves the party. He opens a limo door and looks back at his house. The party continues. The limo drives off. We HOLD on Jean's building. INT. LIMO - NIGHT The limo floats through the streets. Jean stares out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here... Pull over. The limo pulls over. Jean exits. EXT. STREET - NIGHT Jean disappears around the corner. ANGLE ON THREE KIDS in the process of prying a door panel with crowbars. We see that they're removing one of Jean's SAMO pieces from a wall. We read: "PAY FOR SOUP BUILD A FORT SET IT ON FIRE" Jean arrives behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mind your own fuckin' business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's mine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That ain't yours, man. Some asshole named
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INSERT The screen is filled with the cover of the New York Times Magazine. Jean is featured on the cover, without his dreadlocks. INT. GREAT JONES ST. LOFT - NIGHT As Shenge opens the door, a CROWD of people spill out. They pour into the loft. The studio is crowded with PEOPLE. (Many of them we recognize from earlier scenes in Mudd Club, Jean's opening, etc). On the wall there is a portrait of Jean by Andy. The background is a piss painting. Inside, Jean kneels on the floor in the corner of the loft with a bunch of people around him - girls, mostly. Twenty-five copies of the Times Magazine lay stacked on the floor. Crouching on one knee, Jean signs a copy for a BRUNETTE. Looking up -
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: FOR SOUP BUILD A FORT SET IT ON FIRE"

direction.raw_text: did this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's dead. That's what I heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He ain't dead yet. He's gonna kill himself. That's why all those art fags in Soho are paying more every time we bring one of these in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stupid SAMO... Hardly any of this shit left. The panel is almost pried free without a scratch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This one's damn nice. I say we hang onto it if he's almost dead. Jean shoves his way in front with a magic marker and adds a couple words; now it reads: "SAMO IS DEAD" BASQUIAT There you go. Now it's worth more. The kids are outraged, thinking Jean's ruined their find. They jump on him. They beat the shit out of him. They're done. Jean lies curled up on the ground, trying to talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm SAMO... I'm SAMO...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (bending close) He says he's SAMO. Kid #1 whacks him in the back once more for good measure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : THE SEA It is flat, dead, gray. Ominous and waiting. INT. GREAT JONES ST. LOFT - DAY Washed in sunlight, a large painting leans against the wall, the words "HAITIAN BASEBALL FACTORIES" scrawled through its center. Jean lays down, watching TV. He looks older now, more worn. His face is slightly swollen. His complexion is discolored. Shenge covers a triptych with wide brush strokes of yellow paint. He circles a large, primitive figure of a black man drawn with magic marker in the center. He is careful to leave the figure intact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paint it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... Maybe just his arms. (Shenge paints out the arms) Put some Cerulean Blue there. Jean points to the lower corner. Shenge picks up the phone, which has been RINGING for some time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Andy again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still not here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - In this corner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.. Shenge changes the brush and dips it in the can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want me to put it here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Use your fucking instinct. Shenge shrugs and starts to spread the blue. Jean looks at his work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't try to make art. Just paint like a housepainter. A woman's shout can be heard through the open window. Shenge looks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Maria Portos. What should we do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you try letting her in, Steve - I mean Shenge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get up. She won't buy anything if she sees me working on it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wanna bet? If you show too much respect for people with money, they don't have respect for you. MARIA, a raven-haired, sharp-featured beauty in a Chanel suit jacket, blue jeans, and pearls walks into the room. She's with ELLEN - younger - a millionaire fake hippie from Texas. Maria carries a bag with clogs in it - a present for Jean. She takes them out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (showing him the clogs) These reminded me of you, the clogs. I found them in Amsterdam. Jean doesn't get up from the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You remember Ellen? (looking around) What are you working on? Basquiat points at the painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much is something like that? Jean raises his hand and pumps five fingers three times in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifteen. Reasonable. Ellen makes a snotty face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's unfinished. (to Shenge) How 'bout some blue in the corner? Shenge gives Jean a stupefied look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blue? Where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong with you today? Shenge is embarrassed by Jean's remark in the company of the two women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't look at me like that. It hurts my feelings. He points. Unsure, Shenge picks up the brush and paints one of the corners. Maria browses through a stack of paintings leaning against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love these.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God... I just can't even care anymore. Compare this to a mountain or a tree. Who're y'all trying to kid? That's what I think. I was just in the Himalayas, and like - OK - is this important? No. I mean, compared to the rain forest or something? These are just narcissistic jokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Jean) Who are you selling these through now? Jean gets to his feet. He dips a long, thin brush into black paint and nonchalantly crosses out the half figure that Shenge is carefully surrounding with blue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's better. (to Maria) You can buy direct from me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at these - silkscreens? What're you? Andy Warhol Junior? It's like - not even handmade anymore. She's not even worth a response. Jean looks around, numb. INT. MARY BOONE GALLERY - DAY Jean enters the gallery. Cleaned up. Healthier. Bruises healing. He looks like he's been painting. Mary looks up from her desk, surprised to see Jean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jean Michel... Crawling from the wreckage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need a dealer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a bunch of them, don't you? Albert Milo walks in from another room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Jean! (to Mary) It'll never fit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll be ok.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better take a look. Why's your door so small? The ceilings are sixteen feet and your door's the size of a mouse hole!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are your paintings so big? Just go home. I'll get it in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Jean) You doing anything right now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naa..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's get out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See ya in an hour. (to Mary) So what do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bruno spoke to me already. We could talk about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . I'll be at your studio Thursday three o'clock. INT. ALBERT MILO'S LOFT - DAY Albert shows Jean through a series of large rooms filled with enormous paintings. It looks like the Cairo Museum. They pause before a painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is painted on a backdrop from the Kabuki theater in Japan. I painted it after Joseph Beuys died. A rebirth painting. I felt like he could've painted it, or maybe someone else was painting it instead of me. The Chinese calligraphers used to change their name mid-career so they could start over as someone else..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you ever get sick of it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole thing - painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. It's one of the few times I feel good. I used to have to go to work and cook every day. That I got sick of.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about the shit they write?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're asking me this because of the 'lapdog' remark. I read that. The person that wrote that has the compassion of a housefly. That's your enemy, not your audience. Your audience hasn't even been born yet. It's a lie that art is popular. The only thing popular about it is that it's written about in newspapers. I'm surprised when anybody comes to my openings. There're about ten people on the planet who know anything about painting, and Andy's one of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't felt like talking to him since that thing came out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as I've known Andy, he's never asked me for anything except to speak to you about getting off drugs. He's painted my picture, we've eaten dinner in God knows how many places together. But he doesn't care about me. He cares about you. You're the only person he cares about. He's your friend. Fuck that article. You want a toasted bagel with cream cheese? Milo's daughter STELLA (12) calls out from over the balcony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa, the TV's broken... Will you fix it please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. I'll be right up. Albert leaves. Jean looks at some paintings. Stella comes downstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Jean) Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've seen you before. I like your paintings a lot. Your hair was different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like your dad's paintings?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stand still. He draws her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See you later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks He walks to the door, leaving the drawing on the floor. Albert returns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Jean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He just left. Albert opens the door to the stairwell looking for Jean. He hears the sound of URINATING. He leans over the stairwell. He sees Jean Michel, taking a piss on the landing. He shuts the door quietly. EXT. GIFT SHOP WINDOW - DAY Jean walks out of the gift shop (seen earlier, next to beautician's) EXT. BROADWAY AND HOUSTON STREET - DAY Jean walks through the middle of the intersection. He carries two yellow, furry toy ducks under his arm. SUPER: "FEBRUARY 22, 1987" Seeing Bruno at the wheel of a black Mercedes stopped at a light, Jean clowns around like a street vendor who wants to wash his window. Bruno doesn't notice him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .B. It's me - Jean! What's the matter? No snow in Switzerland this year?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You haven't heard? Andy's dead. The light changes. Bruno pulls across the street because of the traffic. Jean drops one of the ducks in the street and walks off. ANGLE ON The duck lying in the street. EXT. GREAT JONES ST. LOFT - NIGHT The "OUT FOR RIBS" sign hangs outside Jean's door. EXT. GREAT JONES ST - DAY Mary sits in her limo trying to call Jean. INT. GREAT JONES ST. LOFT - DAY Near darkness. The curtains are drawn. Music plays: `Birds' by Neil Young: "it's over.....it's over". Jean watches a video tape with the sound MUTED. The screen fills with Andy's face. We SEE a series of quick scenes from his life. Jean and the remaining duck are lit by the TV. INT. GREAT JONES ST. LOFT - DAY EXTREME CLOSEUP: A COLORED PENCIL TIP Held in Jean's hand. It's stalled in mid-stroke. He writes with a magic marker on the heel of two wooden clogs the word: "TITANIC" There's a loud BANGING at the door. When it stops, the pencil tip resumes its long voyage across the page. MUSIC UP: Tom Waits' "Tom Traubert's Blues" EXT. GINA'S APARTMENT - DAY Jean buzzes the doorbell. He's wearing the clogs. He's hurting. The intercom comes on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Gina?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is it? Jean recognizes Benny's voice. ANGLE UP Gina and Benny look out the window into the street. Jean's a block away. EXT. MENTAL HOSPITAL - NIGHT Jean gets out of a cab. He walks up to the entrance. The doors are locked. He rattles them. Inside, an OLD JANITOR keeps mopping. Jean pounds harder, RATTLES the doors more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, come here! Please. Just for a second. Open the door. The janitor gets nervous. He leaves. He returns a moment later with a large SECURITY GUARD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open up! Open up! The guard unlocks the door, hoping to settle Jean down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother's inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come back tomorrow. Visiting hours are over. (beat) Don't cause any trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not here to visit... I wanna take her home. The guard gently ushers Jean out through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't cause any trouble. He locks the door and walks off with the janitor. EXT. STREET - DAYBREAK Jean, walks around, drifting, stoned. He looks up at the skyline.
